title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997". Private security officers in the United States are growing rapidly and function as an adjunct to public law enforcement. The industry provides opportunities for entry-level job applicants and protects individuals and various properties such as banks, hospitals, and airports. Private security officers in the United States provide significant services in various settings such as airports, office complexes, schools, and residential properties. They supplement sworn law enforcement officers and are more likely to be encountered by the public due to the growth of private shopping malls. The trend towards increased security services has accelerated rapidly. The growth of private security services in the United States has accelerated as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased. This trend serves public policy goals by providing more officers to combat serious crimes. The public struggles to differentiate between sworn law enforcement officers and private security personnel, leading to a demand for well-trained private security officers as a supplement, not a replacement, for law enforcement. Private security officers are adjuncts, not replacements for sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers and applicants should undergo thorough screening, especially since many carry weapons. Private security officers and applicants should undergo thorough background checks, especially since many carry weapons. Private security officers can have their fingerprints submitted for background checks at the request of their employer or an association designated by the Attorney General. The Attorney General will search criminal records and provide results within 30 days. Private security officers can have their fingerprints submitted for background checks by an association designated by the Attorney General. The Attorney General will provide identification and criminal history records within 30 business days. The association must use the best technology available for compiling criminal history information and submit employee fingerprints within one business day. Additionally, the association must transfer records to the requesting employer and appropriate licensing authorities promptly. An association designated by the Attorney General must provide copies of requests for identification and criminal history records to licensing authorities and employers. The Attorney General can create regulations for the security, accuracy, and dissemination of information. A report on the number of inquiries made by employers must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary after 2 years. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS.

Subsection (d) of section 534 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include an association of employers of private security officers designated by the Attorney General for conducting background checks.

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY.

Anyone who misuses information obtained under section 3 for purposes other than assessing an individual's suitability for private security officer employment may face a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to two years, or both.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY. Employers relying on criminal history information provided by the Attorney General for employment decisions are not liable for damages. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Attorney General," "employee," "employer," "fingerprint," and "private security officer." The term "fingerprint" includes any approved method of positive identification by the Attorney General. A private security officer is an individual who performs security services for consideration, excluding sworn police officers, licensed professionals, and employees with different primary duties. Employees exempt from being classified as private security officers include licensed professionals in the State, internal audit or credit function employees, individuals on active military duty, electronic security system technicians or monitors, employees involved in secure prisoner movement, and armored vehicle company employees. The term "security services" includes observing and reporting on various activities such as intrusion, theft, vandalism, and unlawful behavior, as well as protecting individuals and property from harm or theft, controlling access to premises, and maintaining order and safety. The term "security services" includes observing and reporting on activities like intrusion, theft, vandalism, and unlawful behavior, protecting individuals and property, controlling access to premises, maintaining order and safety at public events, and providing canine services for protection or detection of unlawful substances. The term "State" refers to various states and territories within the United States. The Attorney General may collect user fees for requests for criminal history information. The effective date of this Act is July 1, 1999.
